entry.lines:
getImplicitPermissionsForUser gets implicit permissions for a user or role. Compared to getPermissionsForUser(), this function retrieves permissions for inherited roles. For example: p, admin, data1, read p, alice, data2, read g, alice, admin
getPermissionsForUser("alice") can only get: [["alice", "data2", "read"]]. But getImplicitPermissionsForUser("alice") will get: [["admin", "data1", "read"], ["alice", "data2", "read"]].
entry.p: implicit permissions for a user or role.
getImplicitPermissionsForUserInDomain gets implicit permissions for a user or role in domain.
implicit permissions for a user or role in domain.

entry.lines:
getImplicitRolesForUser gets implicit roles that a user has. Compared to getRolesForUser(), this function retrieves indirect roles besides direct roles. For example: g, alice, role:admin g, role:admin, role:user
getRolesForUser("alice") can only get: ["role:admin"]. But getImplicitRolesForUser("alice") will get: ["role:admin", "role:user"].
entry.p: implicit roles that a user has.
getPermissionsForUser gets permissions for a user or role.
the permissions, a permission is usually like (obj, act). It is actually the rule without the subject.
getPermissionsForUserInDomain gets permissions for a user or role inside a domain.
the permissions, a permission is usually like (obj, act). It is actually the rule without the subject.
getRolesForUser gets the roles that a user has.
the roles that the user has.
getRolesForUserInDomain gets the roles that a user has inside a domain.
the roles that the user has in the domain.
getUsersForRole gets the users that has a role.
the users that has the role.

entry.p: addFunction adds a customized function.

entry.p: addGroupingPolicy adds a role inheritance rule to the current policy. If the rule already exists, the function returns false and the rule will not be added. Otherwise the function returns true by adding the new rule.

ul.li: params- params the "g" policy rule, ptype "g" is implicitly used.

entry.p: succeeds or not.

getAllActions gets the list of actions that show up in the current policy.
all the actions in "p" policy rules. It actually collects the 2-index elements of "p" policy rules. So make sure your action is the 2-index element, like (sub, obj, act). Duplicates are removed.
GetAllNamedActions gets the list of actions that show up in the current named policy.

ul.li: ptype- ptype the policy type, can be "p", "p2", "p3", ..

entry.p: all the actions in policy rules of the ptype type. It actually collects the 2-index elements of the policy rules. So make sure your action is the 2-index element, like (sub, obj, act). Duplicates are removed.
getAllNamedObjects gets the list of objects that show up in the current named policy.

ul.li: ptype- ptype the policy type, can be "p", "p2", "p3", ..

entry.p: all the objects in policy rules of the ptype type. It actually collects the 1-index elements of the policy rules. So make sure your object is the 1-index element, like (sub, obj, act). Duplicates are removed.
getAllNamedRoles gets the list of roles that show up in the current named policy.

ul.li: ptype- ptype the policy type, can be "g", "g2", "g3", ..

entry.p: all the subjects in policy rules of the ptype type. It actually collects the 0-index elements of the policy rules. So make sure your subject is the 0-index element, like (sub, obj, act). Duplicates are removed.
GetAllNamedSubjects gets the list of subjects that show up in the currentnamed policy.

ul.li: ptype- ptype the policy type, can be "p", "p2", "p3", ..

entry.p: all the subjects in policy rules of the ptype type. It actually collects the 0-index elements of the policy rules. So make sure your subject is the 0-index element, like (sub, obj, act). Duplicates are removed.
getAllObjects gets the list of objects that show up in the current policy.
all the objects in "p" policy rules. It actually collects the 1-index elements of "p" policy rules. So make sure your object is the 1-index element, like (sub, obj, act). Duplicates are removed.
getAllRoles gets the list of roles that show up in the current policy.
all the roles in "g" policy rules. It actually collects the 1-index elements of "g" policy rules. So make sure your role is the 1-index element, like (sub, role). Duplicates are removed.
getAllSubjects gets the list of subjects that show up in the current policy.
all the subjects in "p" policy rules. It actually collects the 0-index elements of "p" policy rules. So make sure your subject is the 0-index element, like (sub, obj, act). Duplicates are removed.

entry.lines:
getImplicitPermissionsForUser gets implicit permissions for a user or role. Compared to getPermissionsForUser(), this function retrieves permissions for inherited roles. For example: p, admin, data1, read p, alice, data2, read g, alice, admin
getPermissionsForUser("alice") can only get: [["alice", "data2", "read"]]. But getImplicitPermissionsForUser("alice") will get: [["admin", "data1", "read"], ["alice", "data2", "read"]].
entry.p:
getImplicitPermissionsForUser in class
Enforcer
implicit permissions for a user or role.

entry.lines:
getImplicitRolesForUser gets implicit roles that a user has. Compared to getRolesForUser(), this function retrieves indirect roles besides direct roles. For example: g, alice, role:admin g, role:admin, role:user
getRolesForUser("alice") can only get: ["role:admin"]. But getImplicitRolesForUser("alice") will get: ["role:admin", "role:user"].

body.lines:
GroupRoleManager is used for authorization if the user's group is the role who has permission, but the group information is in the default format (policy start with "g") and the role information is in named format (policy start with "g2", "g3", ...). e.g. p, admin, domain1, data1, read g, alice, group1 g2, group1, admin, domain1
As for the previous example, alice should have the permission to read data1, but if we use the DefaultRoleManager, it will return false. GroupRoleManager is to handle this situation.
